SENT.plain: The role of reflux in the development of esophagitis, stricture, and Barrett's esophagus is well recognized
However, reflux is not an infrequent cause of atypical chest pain, chronic pulmonary disorders, and pharyngeal and laryngeal changes
Increased insight into the pathogenesis of reflux and the relationship between the gastroesophageal junction and the diaphragmatic crura has led to more effective treatment approaches
Medical therapy, including lifestyle changes, antacids, and systemic agents, is effective in most patients
However, surgery may be necessary in patients with anatomic abnormalities or mechanical dysfunction
